bioghist.p: Merchant’s Gargling Oil was launched in 1833 by George W. Merchant, a pharmacist of Lockport, New York. His Universal Family Embrocation was esteemed along the Erie Canal where it was used to heal the bleeding sores of the horses and mules that pulled the boats along the Canal. Word of mouth approval led to the concoction then known as Merchant's Gargling Oil to be used as a liniment "for man and beast". Merchant's formula was sold to M. H. Tucker in 1855. Merchant’s Gargling Oil was still made in 1933, 100 years after its introduction.

scopecontent.p: This is a collection of papers related to M. H. Tucker & Co's Merchant's Gargling Oil. Items include: an 1870 almanac, stamped on the back with the name of a sales agent, Chas. R. Walker, Richville, New York; printed testimonials; and a bill of sale and two receipts (1856-1857) for products sold to Johnston & Keller, Boalsburg, Pennsylvania, with instructions to sales agents on the reverse.

accessrestrict.p: The collection is open for research.
